Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Wearable technology that provides real-time comfort data to smart buildings and personalized comfort to occupants
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to introduce wearable personal comfort systems into the internet of things, reducing energy consumption in buildings while improving the comfort and well-being of building occupants. EMBR Labs? proprietary wearable technology generates real-time comfort data, enabling reduced and optimized HVAC loads, while simultaneously providing personalized comfort to occupants. Personal comfort systems have the potential to reduce building energy consumption by 20-40% and improve occupant productivity by 2-7%. Providing this technology in commercial buildings could generate a return on investment in under 6 months while adding value for building occupants, facilities managers, and business owners. The R&D supported by this SBIR Phase I could save $B of dollars in energy costs, recapture over $20B of lost productivity.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project develops a personal comfort Internet of Things technology to resolve fundamental inefficiencies in the current approaches to maintaining the comfort and productivity of the American workforce in offices, hospitals, schools, and government buildings. The objectives of this project are to (i) demonstrate the technical feasibility of a wearable personal comfort system that is sufficiently ergonomic for adoption in the workplace, (ii) quantify the ability for the wearable technology to improve occupant comfort, and (iii) demonstrate the ability to collect real-time comfort data from the wearable personal comfort system. This SBIR Phase I project will culminate in the demonstration, validation, and quantification of wearable technology that provides real-time comfort data to smart buildings and personalized comfort to occupants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Embr Labs is making the noise-cancelling headphones of personal comfort. In the United States we use more than 12% of all energy to heat and cool buildings and yet, because of individual differences in temperature preferences, over 40% of workers in office buildings find their environment disruptively uncomfortable. This Phase I R&D is focused on demonstrating the feasibility of wearable technology that allows individual occupants to control their perceived room temperature, improving their personal comfort, productivity and well-being, while generating real-time occupant comfort data that helps reduce and optimize the overall HVAC load in a building. Intelligent, connected personal comfort systems could save our country tens of billions of dollars in energy costs and salvage tens of billions of dollars in lost productivity.

This R&D is supporting a transformative approach for delivering thermal comfort to building occupants. At present, the mechanisms underlying thermal comfort in humans are still poorly understood, which has limited the development of personal comfort solutions in buildings and continues to leave over 20% of occupants feeling thermally uncomfortable. According to UC Berkeley Center for the Built Environment Director Ed Arens, this research “presses the current knowledge of human comfort mechanisms to the limit”, and “is practically and scientifically interesting.”  

Supported by this Phase I R&D, Embr Labs demonstrated a wearable device that leverages localized cooling/warming and extremely low power consumption (1-2 W) to meaningfully improve whole-body thermal sensation.  Scientists at UC Berkeley found that the low-power wearable devices had a statistically significant corrective effect on perceived room temperature and personal thermal comfort. The average corrective power was found to be over 5°F for both heating and cooling. Furthermore, data generated by the devices in the laboratory setting was shown to correlate well with the thermal preferences of occupants. This demonstrates that the connected wearable personal comfort systems can be used to reduce and optimize HVAC load in smart buildings.

This R&D “is assured of making a significant contribution to the future of thermal environmental conditioning in buildings throughout the world,” according to UC Berkeley Center for the Built Environment Director Ed Arens. The wearable technology will provide overdue relief for the thermally-underserved 20% of America’s workforce (who are disproportionately female or part of the aging population), thereby improving their workplace wellbeing, satisfaction, and productivity. Furthermore, Embr Labs’ wearable technology could increase worker productivity by 2-3%, unlocking $17B economic output that is currently lost due to thermal discomfort in the United States. Finally, this R&D could reduce the cost of space heating/cooling buildings by 20-30% by expanding the thermal comfort zone of building occupants by ±6°F and adjusting HVAC thermostat setpoints accordingly. As roughly 10% of the world’s energy is spent heating and cooling the interiors of commercial buildings, the wearable technology in development will make an impactful contribution to the preservation of our planet and the wellbeing of future generations.
